page.title: 05Language
page.content: Although the language in common use is English the area has a dialect of its own. The area was once in Lancashire and has only joined the new administrative area of Cumbria since 1974.The language of this area reflects the language of various European peoples who inhabited it. Ancient Britons, Celts, Norsemen, Anglo Saxons and Normans have all left their mark. The principal village Broughton Mills comes from the Old English 'Broc Tun' meaning the farmstead or hamlet by the stream. The 'Mills' is a reflection of the several water powered mills which existed in these valleys with their ready supply of water. Much of the dialect used locally reflects the agricultural roots of the area. The increasing viewing of television is slowly changing this.
